field_reports.description:
A 6.2M earthquake with an epicenter near Petrinja, December 29th at 11:19 AM CET. There is a larger number of injured people and one confirmed casualty. At least several people are trapped in the ruins. Massive damage to buildings. This earthquake came after a 5.0M earthquake that hit the same area yesterday. The nearby city of Sisak also sustained significant damage. Red Cross teams are on the field with other first responders and more information will be available soon. The earthquake was also strongly felt in Zagreb.

Aftershocks are happening quite often, with varying intensity.

The hospitals in Petrinja and the bigger one in Sisak are damaged. The majority of patients has been evacuated towards Zagreb by emergency vehicles, but also by helicopters. The hospital in Sisak is now used only for first screening of injured from earthquake. There is no definitive number of injured and killed as of yet, but new information is coming in often – around 14,30 hours there was some 20 people injured. 
 
Accommodation for evacuated people from Petrinja and Glina has been organized in military barracks in Petrinja, which has a capacity at least 500 people. People are also being evacuated to the nearby "Topusko" hotel, as well as the sport hall in Glina and elementary schools in Sisak. Tents will be also used. 
 
In Zagreb, the building of Ministry of Defence has sustained significant damaged, as did two large hospitals in Zagreb.  
 
Some parts of the affected areas are still without electricity.
 
CRC teams are on the field in Petrinja since the morning of Dec 29th,  dealing with the consequences of the yesterdays earthquake when the new earthquake hit the area. Other CRC intervention teams are incoming or have already arrived to Petrinja, Glina and Sisak.

field_reports.description: Around 6.28 local time (GMT+1) in the morning, central Croatia (city of Petrinja region) was hit by a magnitude 5.0 earthquake, followed by another at a magnitude 4,7 and 4,1 around 7.50 local time (GMT+1). According to field reports so far there is no injured persons. First report indicated serious material damages mainly on the chimneys and roofs on a significant number of houses. Croatian Red Cross, Disaster Response Team members are operational, assessing emergency needs of the affected population

results.summary:
On 29 December 2020 at 12:19 PM CET (11:19 UTC), a devastating earthquake of 6.2 magnitude1 struck with the epicenter approximately 3 km from Petrinja, which is located some 50 km from Zagreb. The earthquake was strongly felt throughout northern Croatia and especially in Zagreb, as well as in area of large parts of Slovenia, Bosnia and Herzegovina, Serbia, Austria, Hungary and Italy.

As a result of the earthquake on 29 December 2020, almost all buildings in Petrinja and Glina area have been damaged or destroyed, particularly those in the old historical center of Sisak as well as multilevel housing buildings in Hrvatska Kostajnica. Heavy damages to housing have been reported in outskirts of Zagreb County and Karlovac County, as well as in the center of Zagreb City, where the buildings already damaged in March 2020 earthquake.

As of 6th January, there is currently no official data on how many houses and housing building were damaged, but according to the first estimations, there are at least 20,000 damaged buildings in Sisak-Moslavina County with damages estimated at HRK 3 billion (CHF 434,8 million) that will need reconstruction.

As of 1st January,  a total of 833 people were in temporary shelters – the number has been changing from day to day as people are coming in or moving out. According to rough estimations, at least around 2,500 families, with 6,250 family members from the area who are temporary accommodated somewhere else or are waiting for housing containers outside their houses. The CRC estimates a much larger number of people who are still in need of temporary accommodation given the number of people in Petrinja, Glina, Hrvatska Kostajnica and Sisak who refuse temporary accommodation and the number of damaged houses.

Croatian Red Cross response

Following the earthquake, CRC has activated the Emergency Operations Centre (EOC) coordinating with neighboring National Societies to update on the situation, ongoing response and needs. CRC created in NICS software earthquake incident map and other NSs offering support also mapped available capacities through NICS for response in case of needs.

In response, 176 CRC staff and volunteers joined the search and rescue operation along with firefighters, police and civil protection department, providing first aid to the people rescued from the ruins. The search and rescue civil protection teams were operating on 29 and 30 December inspecting the ruins and looking for people who remained trapped beneath them.

Other CRC emergency teams arrived in the field during the afternoon of the 29 December and set up logistics and distribution points, as well as temporary accommodation. The CRC PSS team provided vital support for a family who’s missing a daughter was found dead in a collapsed building. In Sisak at the request of the local crisis headquarters, CRC teams assisted with the evacuation of the hospital, transferring COVID19 patients to Zagreb, as well as preparing part of the hospital for the reception of victims, and triage.

In the first 24 hours the CRC and our local branches teams reached at least some 8,000 people with search and rescue activities, evacuation and distribution of humanitarian aid in food and non-food items as well as first psyhosocial assistance. In the first 24 hours, the CRC deployed a total of 261 staff and volunteers. 

As of 4th January, CRC distributed a total of 287 tons of food, 203,930 litres of water in bottles, 61,782 hot meals, 10,725 litres of tea, 31,141 kg of hygiene items, 1,010 packages of children’s food and household items, 41,6 tons of clothes, 1,091 blankets, 623 heaters, 76 electricity generators, beds and mattresses, cattle food as well as 10,911 hot meals for all Emergency Services on the ground. Overall, 600 staff and volunteers have been mobilised on a rotational basis. Local CRC branches from other parts of Croatia are assisting on the ground with their emergency teams as well as logistics to the operation.
